segments.text: In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I’ve been turning over in my mind ever since. He didn’t say any more, but we’d always been unusually communicative in a reserved way, and I understood there was a deeper meaning behind his words. This advice, along with many experiences—including my college days when I was accused of being a politician for keeping my judgments reserved—shaped my outlook on people and life. I learned that reserving judgment is a matter of infinite hope; yet, as life goes on, even tolerance has its limits. In all these musings, one figure stands apart: Gatsby, the enigmatic man who represented for me both an extraordinary gift for hope and the inexorable corruption left by dreams.

segments.text: That single sentence would echo in my mind through the years—a reminder to reserve judgment and to be cautious of those abnormal minds that attach themselves to the seemingly modest qualities of a normal person. Later, in college, I found myself privy to secret griefs and confessions that were as often unsought as they were impossible to dismiss. Still, I remain aware of my own limits when it comes to tolerance and sentiment. And amid these reflections, my thoughts kept returning to Gatsby, a man whose very presence shimmered with a sort of heightened sensitivity to life’s promises.

segments.text: I came from a family that had been prominent and well-to-do in our Middle Western city for three generations—the Carraways, a clan with a storied past. After graduating from New Haven in 1915 and returning from a restless stint in the war, I decided to head East to learn the bond business. With the backing of my father and the cautious encouragement of my extended family, I made my way here. In search of a place to call home, I arranged to share a house once, though fate had other plans; soon, I found myself alone with an old Dodge, a fleeting canine companion, and a hardworking Finnish woman who cooked and mended the home with quiet wisdom.

segments.text: Later that night, after dinner had dwindled into muted farewells and the soft glow of candlelight faded into dusk, I left the Buchanan residence. Driving back to West Egg, I pulled into my modest estate. There, in the deep summer night, a mysterious figure emerged from the shadow of Gatsby’s mansion. With his hands in his pockets and a quiet, almost trembling posture, he stood by the water, stretching his arms toward the dark. In that moment, a solitary green light—a tiny beacon at the end of a dock—seemed to capture all the hopeful dreams and lingering sorrows of our neighborhood.
